ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: The professor just stood there the entire class, for every single class, while students talked. No conversation was stimulated whatsoever from the professor. Easy A.

Everyone talked about their experiences with civic education, usually with some relation to theories and techniques presented in weekly readings. It was interesting to hear what people did and where they came from. We also developed reading and reasoning skills in social science to understand the empirical work on civic education.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Isn't a professor supposed to teach?

The course has well-selected and diverse readings which provide an interesting array of topics. The course also invites student anecdotes, which illustrate real experiences alongside the more theoretical or analytical readings. The course suffers, however, from occasional disorganization. Discussion of anecdotes often displaced discussion of readings, and they would benefit from separate spaces. The class decided not to have a discussion post requirement at the beginning of the semester, but in retrospect, we would have benefited from the extra preparation.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, if you want an A. You literally do not need to do anything. Not a single homework assignment. I am not kidding.

Yes. The course is what it makes itself out to be. Professor Fairdosi assigns students to lead the discussion in seminar, and he participates accordingly. The class is interesting from a reflective perspective and casts a new light on my experiences as a student of civic education. And it informs my idea of how civics should be taught.
